documentation.text: @return l2Block return L2 block when the L2 tx was initiated or 0 if no L2 to L1 transaction is active
@return l1Block return L1 block when the L2 tx was initiated or 0 if no L2 to L1 transaction is active
@return timestamp return L2 timestamp when the L2 tx was initiated or 0 if no L2 to L1 transaction is active
@return outputId returns the unique output identifier of the L2 to L1 tx or 0 if no L2 to L1 transaction is active

@dev function used to simulate the result of a particular function call from the outbox
       it is useful for things such as gas estimates. This function includes all costs except for
       proof validation (which can be considered offchain as a somewhat of a fixed cost - it's
       not really a fixed cost, but can be treated as so with a fixed overhead for gas estimation).
       We can't include the cost of proof validation since this is intended to be used to simulate txs
       that are included in yet-to-be confirmed merkle roots. The simulation entrypoint could instead pretend
       to confirm a pending merkle root, but that would be less practical for integrating with tooling.
       It is only possible to trigger it when the msg sender is address zero, which should be impossible
       unless under simulation in an eth_call or eth_estimateGas

@param index Merkle path to message
 @return true if the message has been spent

executeTransaction(bytes32[],uint256,add.details: Reverts if dispute period hasn't expired, since the outbox entry      is only created once the rollup confirms the respective assertion.it is not possible to execute any L2-to-L1 transaction which contains data      to a contract address without any code (as enforced by the Bridge contract).

params.l1Block: l1 block number at which sendTxToL1 call was made
params.l2Block: l2 block number at which sendTxToL1 call was made
params.l2Sender: sender if original message (i.e., caller of ArbSys.sendTxToL1)
params.l2Timestamp: l2 Timestamp at which sendTxToL1 call was made
params.proof: Merkle proof of message inclusion in send root
params.to: destination address for L1 contract call

executeTransactionSimulation(uint256,add.details: function used to simulate the result of a particular function call from the outbox       it is useful for things such as gas estimates. This function includes all costs except for       proof validation (which can be considered offchain as a somewhat of a fixed cost - it's       not really a fixed cost, but can be treated as so with a fixed overhead for gas estimation).       We can't include the cost of proof validation since this is intended to be used to simulate txs       that are included in yet-to-be confirmed merkle roots. The simulation entrypoint could instead pretend       to confirm a pending merkle root, but that would be less practical for integrating with tooling.       It is only possible to trigger it when the msg sender is address zero, which should be impossible       unless under simulation in an eth_call or eth_estimateGas

returns._0: true if the message has been spent
l2Block return L2 block when the L2 tx was initiated or 0 if no L2 to L1 transaction is active
l1Block return L1 block when the L2 tx was initiated or 0 if no L2 to L1 transaction is active
outputId returns the unique output identifier of the L2 to L1 tx or 0 if no L2 to L1 transaction is active

l2ToL1Sender().details: the l2ToL1Sender behaves as the tx.origin, the msg.sender should be validated to protect against reentrancies

returns._0: timestamp return L2 timestamp when the L2 tx was initiated or 0 if no L2 to L1 transaction is active

executeTransaction(bytes32[],uint256,add.notice: Executes a messages in an Outbox entry.

l2ToL1Sender().notice: When l2ToL1Sender returns a nonzero address, the message was originated by an L2 account         When the return value is zero, that means this is a system message
